12.passage:
Nothing!

"What on earth put such a notion into your head?" [MASK] demanded disapprovingly.

20.passage:
He can't be much different from ourselves."

"Well, I hope it will turn out all right," said [MASK] in a tone that plainly indicated her painful doubts. "Only don't say I didn't warn you if he burns Green Gables down or puts strychnine in the well--I heard of a case over in New Brunswick where an orphan asylum child did that and the whole family died in fearful agonies.

22.passage:
Only, it was a girl in that instance."

"Well, we're not getting a girl," said [MASK], as if poisoning wells were a purely feminine accomplishment and not to be dreaded in the case of a boy. "I'd never dream of taking a girl to bring up.

27.passage: The five-thirty train has been in and gone half an hour ago," answered [MASK]. "But there was a passenger dropped off for you--a little girl. She's sitting out there on the shingles. I asked her to go into the ladies' waiting room, but she informed me gravely that she preferred to stay outside. ?There was more scope for imagination,' she said.

29.passage:
She's a case, I should say."

"I'm not expecting a girl," said [MASK] blankly. "It's a boy I've come for.

35.passage:
Well, you'd better question the girl," said the station-master carelessly. "I dare say she'll be able to explain--she's got a tongue of her own, that's certain. Maybe they were out of boys of the brand you wanted."

He walked jauntily away, being hungry, and the unfortunate [MASK] was left to do that which was harder for him than bearding a lion in its den--walk up to a girl--a strange girl--an orphan girl--and demand of her why she wasn't a boy.

38.passage:
She couldn't be left at Bright River anyhow, no matter what mistake had been made, so all questions and explanations might as well be deferred until he was safely back at Green Gables.

"I'm sorry I was late," [MASK] said shyly. "Come along.

40.passage:
Give me your bag."

"Oh, I can carry it," [MASK] responded cheerfully. "It isn't heavy.

42.passage:
The child put out her hand and broke off a branch of wild plum that brushed against the side of the buggy.

"Isn't that beautiful? What did that tree, leaning out from the bank, all white and lacy, make you think of?" [MASK] asked.

43.passage:
she asked.

"Well now, I dunno," said [MASK].

"Why, a bride, of course--a bride all in white with a lovely misty veil.

45.passage:
And what _does_ make the roads red?"

"Well now, I dunno," said [MASK].

"Well, that is one of the things to find out sometime.

48.passage:
So [MASK] said as shyly as usual:

"Oh, you can talk as much as you like. I don't mind."

"Oh, I'm so glad.

56.passage:
The girl let the braid drop back with a sigh that seemed to come from her very toes and to exhale forth all the sorrows of the ages.

"Yes, it's red," [MASK] said resignedly. "Now you see why I can't be perfectly happy.

59.passage:
Can you tell me?"

"Well now, I'm afraid I can't," said [MASK], who was getting a little dizzy. He felt as he had once felt in his rash youth when another boy had enticed him on the merry-go-round at a picnic.

61.passage:
Have you ever imagined what it must feel like to be divinely beautiful?"

"Well now, no, I haven't," confessed [MASK] ingenuously.

"I have, often.

66.passage:
I guess you're feeling pretty tired and hungry," [MASK] ventured to say at last, accounting for her long visitation of dumbness with the only reason he could think of. "But we haven't very far to go now--only another mile."

She came out of her reverie with a deep sigh and looked at him with the dreamy gaze of a soul that had been wondering afar, star-led.

70.passage:
Well now, you must mean the Avenue," said [MASK] after a few moments' profound reflection. "It is a kind of pretty place."

"Pretty?

88.passage:
That's Green Gables over--"

"Oh, don't tell me," [MASK] interrupted breathlessly, catching at his partially raised arm and shutting her eyes that she might not see his gesture. "Let me guess. I'm sure I'll guess right."

She opened her eyes and looked about her.

89.passage:
Over it, in the stainless southwest sky, a great crystal-white star was shining like a lamp of guidance and promise.

"That's it, isn't it?" [MASK] said, pointing.

93.passage:
Listen to the trees talking in their sleep," [MASK] whispered, as he lifted her to the ground. "What nice dreams they must have!"

Then, holding tightly to the carpet-bag which contained "all her worldly goods," she followed him into the house.

97.passage:
There wasn't any boy," said [MASK] wretchedly. "There was only _her_."

He nodded at the child, remembering that he had never even asked her name.

102.passage:
Dropping her precious carpet-bag she sprang forward a step and clasped her hands.

"You don't want me!" [MASK] cried.

131.passage:
Can you eat when you are in the depths of despair?"

"I've never been in the depths of despair, so I can't say," responded [MASK].

"Weren't you?

144.passage:
This girl will have to be sent back to the asylum."

"Yes, I suppose so," said [MASK] reluctantly.

"You _suppose_ so!

149.passage:
Well, now, no, I suppose not--not exactly," stammered [MASK], uncomfortably driven into a corner for his precise meaning. "I suppose--we could hardly be expected to keep her."

"I should say not.

154.passage:
Well now, she's a real interesting little thing," persisted [MASK]. "You should have heard her talk coming from the station."

"Oh, she can talk fast enough.

164.passage:
she said, waving her hand comprehensively at the good world outside.

"It's a big tree," said [MASK], "and it blooms great, but the fruit don't amount to much never--small and wormy."

"Oh, I don't mean just the tree; of course it's lovely--yes, it's _radiantly_ lovely--it blooms as if it meant it--but I meant everything, the garden and the orchard and the brook and the woods, the whole big dear world.

167.passage:
But the worst of imagining things is that the time comes when you have to stop and that hurts."

"You'd better get dressed and come down-stairs and never mind your imaginings," said [MASK] as soon as she could get a word in edgewise. "Breakfast is waiting.

178.passage:
I felt that he was a kindred spirit as soon as ever I saw him."

"You're both queer enough, if that's what you mean by kindred spirits,"  said [MASK] with a sniff. "Yes, you may wash the dishes.

199.passage:
That's a sentence I read in a book once, and I say it over to comfort myself whenever I'm disappointed in anything."

"I don't see where the comforting comes in myself," said [MASK].

"Why, because it sounds so nice and romantic, just as if I were a heroine in a book, you know.

202.passage:
We're going by the shore road."

"Shore road sounds nice," said [MASK] dreamily. "Is it as nice as it sounds?

207.passage:
Oh, what I _know_ about myself isn't really worth telling," said [MASK] eagerly. "If you'll only let me tell you what I _imagine_ about myself you'll think it ever so much more interesting."

"No, I don't want any of your imaginings.

209.passage:
Where were you born and how old are you?"

"I was eleven last March," said [MASK], resigning herself to bald facts with a little sigh. "And I was born in Bolingbroke, Nova Scotia.

216.passage:
Evidently she did not like talking about her experiences in a world that had not wanted her.

"Did you ever go to school?" demanded [MASK], turning the sorrel mare down the shore road.

"Not a great deal.

220.passage:
Her sensitive little face suddenly flushed scarlet and embarrassment sat on her brow. "Oh, they _meant_ to be--I know they meant to be just as good and kind as possible. And when people mean to be good to you, you don't mind very much when they're not quite--always. They had a good deal to worry them, you know. It's  a very trying to have a drunken husband, you see; and it must be very trying to have twins three times in succession, don't you think? But I feel sure they meant to be good to me."

[MASK] asked no more questions.

221.passage:
He was set on it; and the child seemed a nice, teachable little thing.

"She's got too much to say," thought [MASK], "but she might be trained out of that. And there's nothing rude or slangy in what she does say.

238.passage:
I've often had to scold her well for her heedlessness."

"It was our own fault," said [MASK] resignedly. "We should have come to you ourselves and not left an important message to be passed along by word of mouth in that fashion.

275.passage:
I haven't any use at all for little girls who aren't neat."

"I was so harrowed up in my mind last night that I didn't think about my clothes at all," said [MASK]. "I'll fold them nicely tonight.

277.passage:
Half the time, though, I'd forget, I'd be in such a hurry to get into bed nice and quiet and imagine things."

"You'll have to remember a little better if you stay here," admonished [MASK]. "There, that looks something like.

285.passage:
I'm afraid you are a very bad little girl."

"You'd find it easier to be bad than good if you had red hair," said [MASK] reproachfully. "People who haven't red hair don't know what trouble is.

297.passage:
I remain,                     "Yours respectfully,                        [MASK].

"There, did I do all right?" she asked eagerly, getting up.

300.passage:
Do you suppose it will make any difference?"

"I--I don't suppose it will," said [MASK]. "Go to sleep now like a good child.

309.passage:
Why, child, whatever is the matter?"

"I'm crying," said [MASK] in a tone of bewilderment. "I can't think why.

311.passage:
But can you tell me why I'm crying?"

"I suppose it's because you're all excited and worked up," said [MASK] disapprovingly. "Sit down on that chair and try to calm yourself.

329.passage:
There's to be no more of such praying as I heard last night."

"I suppose I was very awkward," said [MASK] apologetically, "but then, you see, I'd never had any practice.

340.passage: I like this," [MASK] announced at length. "It's beautiful. I've heard it before--I heard the superintendent of the asylum Sunday school say it over once. But I didn't like it then. He had such a cracked voice and he prayed it so mournfully. I really felt sure he thought praying was a disagreeable duty. This isn't poetry, but it makes me feel just the same way poetry does. ?Our Father who art in heaven hallowed be Thy name.'

351.passage:
I had become so attached to her that I hadn't the heart to imagine a bosom friend at the asylum, even if there had been any scope for imagination there."

"I think it's just as well there wasn't," said [MASK] drily. "I don't approve of such goings-on.

354.passage:
If I wasn't a human girl I think I'd like to be a bee and live among the flowers."

"Yesterday you wanted to be a sea gull," sniffed [MASK]. "I think you are very fickle minded.

358.passage:
Go to your room and finish learning it well, and stay there until I call you down to help me get tea."

"Can I take the apple blossoms with me for company?" pleaded [MASK].

"No; you don't want your room cluttered up with flowers.

360.passage:
You should have left them on the tree in the first place."

"I did feel a little that way, too," said [MASK]. "I kind of felt I shouldn't shorten their lovely lives by picking them--I wouldn't want to be picked if I were an apple blossom.

371.passage:
I'm getting over my surprise now."

"It was too bad there was such a mistake," said [MASK] sympathetically. "Couldn't you have sent her back?"

"I suppose we could, but we decided not to.

380.passage: I hate you," [MASK] cried in a choked voice, stamping her foot on the floor. "I hate you--I hate you--I hate you--" a louder stamp with each assertion of hatred. "How dare you call me skinny and ugly?

399.passage:
You say it yourself often enough."

"Oh, but there's such a difference between saying a thing yourself and hearing other people say it," wailed [MASK]. "You may know a thing is so, but you can't help hoping other people don't quite think it is.

412.passage:
I'm sorry."

"Perhaps your imagination will be in better working order by the morning," said [MASK], rising to depart. "You'll have the night to think over your conduct in and come to a better frame of mind.

416.passage:
I suppose you'll be saying next thing that she oughtn't to be punished at all!"

"Well now--no--not exactly," said [MASK] uneasily. "I reckon she ought to be punished a little.

428.passage:
That's what I was trying to get at."

"I suppose I could do it to oblige you," said [MASK] thoughtfully. "It would be true enough to say I am sorry, because I _am_ sorry now.

458.passage:
I'm afraid you are a very vain little girl."

"How can I be vain when I know I'm homely?" protested [MASK]. "I love pretty things; and I hate to look in the glass and see something that isn't pretty.

466.passage:
And you should never find it hard to say your prayers."

"Saying one's prayers isn't exactly the same thing as praying," said [MASK] meditatively. "But I'm going to imagine that I'm the wind that is blowing up there in those tree tops.

481.passage:
I prefer the plain, sensible ones."

"But I'd rather look ridiculous when everybody else does than plain and sensible all by myself," persisted [MASK] mournfully.

"Trust you for that!

501.passage:
A pretty-looking object you must have been!"

"Oh. I know pink and yellow aren't becoming to me," began [MASK].

"Becoming fiddlesticks!

503.passage:
You are the most aggravating child!"

"I don't see why it's any more ridiculous to wear flowers on your hat than on your dress," protested [MASK]. "Lots of little girls there had bouquets pinned on their dresses.

506.passage:
Of course they would think I had no better sense than to let you go decked out like that."

"Oh, I'm so sorry," said [MASK], tears welling into her eyes. "I never thought you'd mind.

508.passage:
But that would be better than being a trial to you."

"Nonsense," said [MASK], vexed at herself for having made the child cry. "I don't want to send you back to the asylum, I'm sure.

530.passage:
There are two kinds, you know."

"I never heard of but one kind," said [MASK] doubtfully.

"There really is another.

534.passage:
How do you do it?"

"We must join hands--so," said [MASK] gravely. "It ought to be over running water.

543.passage:
I heard you say you liked chocolate sweeties, so I got you some," he said.

"Humph," sniffed [MASK]. "It'll ruin her teeth and stomach.

564.passage:
Now, get out your patchwork and have your square done before teatime."

"I do _not_ like patchwork," said [MASK] dolefully, hunting out her workbasket and sitting down before a little heap of red and white diamonds with a sigh. "I think some kinds of sewing would be nice; but there's no scope for imagination in patchwork.

573.passage:
Blessed are they who expect nothing for they shall not be disappointed.' But I think it would be worse to expect nothing than to be disappointed."

[MASK] wore her amethyst brooch to church that day as usual.

584.passage:
I never do the same naughty thing twice."

"You didn't put it back," said [MASK]. "That brooch isn't anywhere on the bureau.

588.passage:
But I'm perfectly certain I put it back."

"I'll go and have another look," said [MASK], determining to be just. "If you put that brooch back it's there still.

595.passage:
Go to your room and stay there until you are ready to confess."

"Will I take the peas with me?" said [MASK] meekly.

"No, I'll finish shelling them myself.

597.passage:
With such an innocent face, too!

"I don't know what I wouldn't sooner have had happen," thought [MASK], as she nervously shelled the peas. "Of course, I don't suppose she meant to steal it or anything like that.

600.passage:
You're sure it hasn't fell down behind the bureau?" was the only suggestion he could offer.

"I've moved the bureau and I've taken out the drawers and I've looked in every crack and cranny" was [MASK]'s positive answer. "The brooch is gone and that child has taken it and lied about it.

603.passage:
He felt no desire to put his oar in this time.

"She'll stay in her room until she confesses," said [MASK] grimly, remembering the success of this method in the former case. "Then we'll see.

620.passage:
You are the very wickedest girl I ever heard of."

"Yes, I suppose I am," agreed [MASK] tranquilly. "And I know I'll have to be punished.

626.passage:
She clasped her hands together, gave a piercing shriek, and then flung herself face downward on the bed, crying and writhing in an utter abandonment of disappointment and despair.

"For the land's sake!" gasped [MASK], hastening from the room. "I believe the child is crazy.

641.passage:
Now I want to know what that rigmarole you told me this morning meant."

"Why, you said you'd keep me here until I confessed," returned [MASK] wearily, "and so I decided to confess because I was bound to get to the picnic. I thought out a confession last night after I went to bed and made it as interesting as I could.

651.passage:
CHAPTER XV. A Tempest in the School Teapot


"WHAT a splendid day!" said [MASK], drawing a long breath. "Isn't it good just to be alive on a day like this?

653.passage:
And it's splendider still to have such a lovely way to go to school by, isn't it?"

"It's a lot nicer than going round by the road; that is so dusty and hot," said [MASK] practically, peeping into her dinner basket and mentally calculating if the three juicy, toothsome, raspberry tarts reposing there were divided among ten girls how many bites each girl would have.

The little girls of Avonlea school always pooled their lunches, and to eat three raspberry tarts all alone or even to share them only with one's best chum would have forever and ever branded as "awful mean" the girl who did it.

664.passage:
I hope you were a good girl."

"Indeed I was," said [MASK] comfortably. "It wasn't so hard as you might imagine, either.

674.passage:
I've heard him say he studied the multiplication table by her freckles."

"Oh, don't speak about freckles to me," implored [MASK]. "It isn't delicate when I've got so many.

676.passage:
I should just like to see anybody dare to write my name up with a boy's. Not, of course," she hastened to add, "that anybody would."

[MASK] sighed.

677.passage:
But it was a little humiliating to know that there was no danger of it.

"Nonsense," said [MASK], whose black eyes and glossy tresses had played such havoc with the hearts of Avonlea schoolboys that her name figured on the porch walls in half a dozen take-notices. "It's only meant as a joke.

679.passage:
That's better than being good looking."

"No, it isn't," said [MASK], feminine to the core. "I'd rather be pretty than clever.

692.passage:
[MASK] exclaimed passionately. "How dare you!"

And then--thwack!

741.passage:
I never thought she'd take with them so well."

"Then you really think I'd better let her stay home," said [MASK] in amazement.

"Yes.

789.passage:
Where do you feel bad?"

"I'm awful dizzy," said [MASK].

And indeed, she walked very dizzily.

801.passage:
Didn't you know the difference yourself?"

"I never tasted it," said [MASK]. "I thought it was the cordial.

805.passage:
I can't see as you were to blame although I'm sorry it happened so."

"I must cry," said [MASK]. "My heart is broken.

848.passage:
In school I can look at her and muse over days departed."

"You'd better muse over your lessons and sums," said [MASK], concealing her delight at this development of the situation. "If you're going back to school I hope we'll hear no more of breaking slates over people's heads and such carryings on.

850.passage:
Behave yourself and do just what your teacher tells you."

"I'll try to be a model pupil," agreed [MASK] dolefully. "There won't be much fun in it, I expect.

890.passage:
You know there are some things that cannot be expressed in words."

"Yes, I know," nodded the doctor. He looked at [MASK] as if he were thinking some things about her that couldn't be expressed in words.

916.passage:
But she wants to see me," pleaded [MASK]. "She has something very important to tell me."

"How do you know she has?"

"Because she just signaled to me from her window.

926.passage:
You're better at home in your own bed, and as for that club concert, it's all nonsense, and little girls should not be allowed to go out to such places at all."

"I'm sure the Debating Club is a most respectable affair," pleaded [MASK].

"I'm not saying it isn't.

955.passage:
It's so nice and warm."

"Hasn't it been a delightful time?" sighed [MASK] rapturously. "It must be splendid to get up and recite there.

972.passage:
I suggested racing to see who would get into bed first."

"I knew it!" said [MASK], with the exultation of a correct guesser. "I knew that idea came out of your head.

988.passage:
why--she'll eat you alive!"

"Don't frighten me any more than I am frightened," implored [MASK]. "I'd rather walk up to a cannon's mouth.

990.passage:
I've had practice in confessing, fortunately."

"Well, she's in the room," said [MASK]. "You can go in if you want to.

1002.passage:
You don't know what it is to be awakened out of a sound sleep, after a long and arduous journey, by two great girls coming bounce down on you."

"I don't _know_, but I can _imagine_," said [MASK] eagerly. "I'm sure it must have been very disturbing.

1006.passage:
Sit down here and tell me about yourself."

"I am very sorry I can't," said [MASK] firmly. "I would like to, because you seem like an interesting lady, and you might even be a kindred spirit although you don't look very much like it.

1018.passage:
We made a real sensation."

"Not much wonder! Such silly doings!" was [MASK]'s response.

After the Mayflowers came the violets, and Violet Vale was empurpled with them.

1023.passage:
I would have endured it joyfully for your sake."

"I guess you did your part in attending to the work and letting me rest," said [MASK]. "You seem to have got on fairly well and made fewer mistakes than usual.

1036.passage:
Go at once and be smart too."

"I'll have to go around by the road, then," said [MASK], taking up her hat reluctantly.

"Go by the road and waste half an hour!

1040.passage:
What under the canopy is the Haunted Wood?"

"The spruce wood over the brook," said [MASK] in a whisper.

"Fiddlesticks!

1055.passage:
What would you feel like if a white thing did snatch me up and carry me off?"

"I'll risk it," said [MASK] unfeelingly. "You know I always mean what I say.

1108.passage:
What flavoring did you use?"

"Vanilla," said [MASK], her face scarlet with mortification after tasting the cake. "Only vanilla.

1144.passage:
I knew a girl in Marysville who could walk the ridgepole of a roof."

"I don't believe it," said [MASK] flatly. "I don't believe anybody could walk a ridgepole.

1173.passage:
Here now, try and eat some supper."

"Isn't it fortunate I've got such an imagination?" said [MASK]. "It will help me through splendidly, I expect.

1209.passage:
We've none on hand just now."

"Oh, certainly--certainly--just as you say," stammered [MASK], seizing the rake and making for the door. At the threshold he recollected that he had not paid for it and he turned miserably back.

1233.passage:
Come now, sit in."

"I don't see how I'm going to eat breakfast," said [MASK] rapturously. "Breakfast seems so commonplace at such an exciting moment.

1259.passage:
I guess she'll need something more than Avonlea school by and by."

"There's time enough to think of that," said [MASK]. "She's only thirteen in March.

1262.passage:
Well now, it'll do no harm to be thinking it over off and on," said [MASK]. "Things like that are all the better for lots of thinking over."

CHAPTER XXVI.

1274.passage:
They're so white and still, as if they were asleep and dreaming pretty dreams."

"I won't mind writing that composition when its time comes," sighed [MASK]. "I can manage to write about the woods, but the one we're to hand in Monday is terrible.

1294.passage:
I mostly always have to tell them what to write about, but that isn't hard for I've millions of ideas."

"I think this story-writing business is the foolishest yet," scoffed [MASK]. "You'll get a pack of nonsense into your heads and waste time that should be put on your lessons.

1349.passage:
I could never have the courage to float down there."

"Nor I," said [MASK], with a shiver. "I don't mind floating down when there's two or three of us in the flat and we can sit up.

1351.passage:
I'd die really of fright."

"Of course it would be romantic," conceded [MASK], "but I know I couldn't keep still. I'd be popping up every minute or so to see where I was and if I wasn't drifting too far out.

1371.passage:
You know [MASK] ?lay as though she smiled.' That's better. Now push the flat off."

The flat was accordingly pushed off, scraping roughly over an old embedded stake in the process.

1392.passage:
Of course you'll speak to him after this."

"Of course I won't," flashed [MASK], with a momentary return of her old spirit. "And I don't want ever to hear the word ?

1396.passage:
A good cry, indulged in the grateful solitude of the east gable, had soothed her nerves and restored her to her wonted cheerfulness. "I think my prospects of becoming sensible are brighter now than ever."

"I don't see how," said [MASK].

1421.passage:
But I dare say you know that without being told."

"Indeed I didn't," said [MASK] radiantly. "I know I'm not so freckled as I used to be, so I've much to be thankful for, but I really hadn't dared to hope there was any other improvement.

1437.passage:
The waves broke with a soft swish on the rocks below them, and the tang of the sea was in the strong, fresh air.

"Oh, but it's good to be alive and to be going home," breathed [MASK].

When she crossed the log bridge over the brook the kitchen light of Green Gables winked her a friendly welcome back, and through the open door shone the hearth fire, sending out its warm red glow athwart the chilly autumn night.

1441.passage:
You don't mean to say you cooked that for me!"

"Yes, I did," said [MASK]. "I thought you'd be hungry after such a drive and need something real appetizing.

1472.passage:
Teacher and taught were alike glad when the term was ended and the glad vacation days stretched rosily before them.

"But you've done good work this past year," [MASK] told them on the last evening, "and you deserve a good, jolly vacation. Have the best time you can in the out-of-door world and lay in a good stock of health and vitality and ambition to carry you through next year.

1475.passage:
The Queen's class listened in breathless suspense for her answer.

"Yes, I think I will," said [MASK]. "I thought of taking another school, but I have decided to come back to Avonlea.

1499.passage:
There isn't a kinder soul in Avonlea and she never shirks her share of work."

"I'm very glad you feel the same," said [MASK] decidedly. "It's so encouraging.

1517.passage:
Sometimes I wake up in the night and wonder what I'll do if I don't pass."

"Why, go to school next year and try again," said [MASK] unconcernedly.

"Oh, I don't believe I'd have the heart for it.

1521.passage:
You oughtn't to feel half as badly as I do," said [MASK], hunting vainly for a dry spot on her handkerchief. "You'll be back again next winter, but I suppose I've left the dear old school forever--if I have good luck, that is."

"It won't be a bit the same.

1547.passage:
I am pretty near crazy as it is, but you're as calm and cool as a spring evening."

"I'm just dazzled inside," said [MASK]. "I want to say a hundred things, and I can't find words to say them in.

1566.passage:
Well, I suppose I shall just have to resign myself to it."

"But you have such dimples," said [MASK], smiling affectionately into the pretty, vivacious face so near her own. "Lovely dimples, like little dents in cream.

1576.passage:
I don't know how I'll get along without it when I go to town next month."

"Don't speak of your going away tonight," begged [MASK]. "I don't want to think of it, it makes me so miserable, and I do want to have a good time this evening.

1587.passage:
How great and still and wonderful everything was, with the murmur of the sea sounding through it and the darkling cliffs beyond like grim giants guarding enchanted coasts.

"Hasn't it been a perfectly splendid time?" sighed [MASK], as they drove away. "I just wish I was a rich American and could spend my summer at a hotel and wear jewels and low-necked dresses and have ice cream and chicken salad every blessed day.

1598.passage:
Wouldn't you just love to be rich, girls?"

"We _are_ rich," said [MASK] staunchly. "Why, we have sixteen years to our credit, and we're happy as queens, and we've all got imaginations, more or less.

1613.passage:
Under the stars of the blue summer night he walked agitatedly across the yard to the gate under the poplars.

"Well now, I guess she ain't been much spoiled," [MASK] muttered, proudly. "I guess my putting in my oar occasional never did much harm after all.

1632.passage:
But in Charlottetown harassed Queen's students thought and talked only of examinations.

"It doesn't seem possible that the term is nearly over," said [MASK]. "Why, last fall it seemed so long to look forward to--a whole winter of studies and classes.

1636.passage:
It would be dreadful if I failed to get my license after going to Queen's all winter and spending so much money."

"_I_ don't care," said [MASK]. "If I don't pass this year I'm coming back next.

1706.passage:
Do you mind the time you dyed your hair?"

"Yes, indeed. I shall never forget it," smiled [MASK], touching the heavy braid of hair that was wound about her shapely head. "I laugh a little now sometimes when I think what a worry my hair used to be to me--but I don't laugh _much_, because it was a very real trouble then.

1717.passage:
I've always kind of wished I'd forgiven him when I had the chance."

"So you've had a bit of romance in your life, too," said [MASK] softly.

"Yes, I suppose you might call it that.

1721.passage:
Yes--no--I don't know," said [MASK] wearily, looking up. "I suppose I am tired but I haven't thought about it. It's not that."

"Did you see the oculist?

1722.passage:
It's not that."

"Did you see the oculist? What did he say?" asked [MASK] anxiously.

"Yes, I saw him.

1725.passage:
If you are careful you won't lose your sight altogether; and if his glasses cure your headaches it will be a great thing."

"I don't call it much hope," said [MASK] bitterly. "What am I to live for if I can't read or sew or do anything like that?

1747.passage:
Nobody could love it as you and I do--so we must keep it."

"You blessed girl!" said [MASK], yielding. "I feel as if you'd given me new life.
